item.title: The Ternary Operator
item.dc:creator: @meiscooldude meiscooldude
item.description:
@meiscooldude wrote:

I was introduced to the ternary operator when i started C#,

C# has another cool operator along with the ternary operator.

here is an example of it:

object first = new object();
object second = new object();
object third = new object();

// first = second, unless second is null, then first = third
first = second ?? third;

// Just a short hand of
first = second != null ? second : third;

anyway, this is a good time to mention the ‘instanceof’ operator in Java,

I havn’t messed around with it yet, but you can basically say this:


Dog pitbull = new PitBull ();
Dog lab = new Lab ();


//True because lab is an instance of the Lab class.
if (lab instanceof Lab)
{
   
}

//kinda cool, but you have to have a good understanding of polymorphism to use it correctly.

Read full topic

item.title: The Ternary Operator
item.dc:creator: @primadude Primadude
item.description:
@primadude wrote:

[quote=“Jc22493, post:21, topic:282057”][quote author=peterbjornx link=topic=372700.msg2870748#msg2870748 date=1247753573]
return a > b ? true : false; should be return a > b;
[/quote]
No. He’s teaching the ternary operator. Yours makes no sense anyways.[/quote]

‘return a > b;’ does the same thing as ‘return a > b ? true : false;’, but I am using it as an example in this tutorial.

Read full topic

item.title: The Ternary Operator
item.dc:creator: @primadude Primadude
item.description:
@primadude wrote:

[quote=“jGod, post:16, topic:282057”][quote author=CAPT_AMERIKA link=topic=372700.msg2818577#msg2818577 date=1244428636]
Took me some looking at and understanding what it is saying lol. So let me see if I understand this correctly;

In order to use this, does it have to be inside a boolean? I mean all the examples you did were with booleans, and they didn’t return a false or true, just a String. Please help verify this for me
[/quote]

Booleans are probably the worst way to use the ternary operator.[/quote]

I know, because you can just return the ‘if’ statement instead of using the ternary operator.

return variableA > variableB;

Read full topic
